paragraphs.text: “He said what?” Lily asked as she licked a spoonful of green tea ice cream. She and I had met at Sushi Samba at nine so I could update her on my first day. My parents had grudgingly forked over the emergencies-only credit card again until I got my first paycheck. Spicy tuna rolls and seaweed salads certainly felt like an emergency, and so I silently thanked Mom and Dad for treating Lily and me so well.

annotations.explanation: 勉强地，心不甘情不愿地。这个词通常用来形容做某事时的态度不情愿，带有一定的抵触情绪。

仅限于紧急情况使用的信用卡。这种卡通常是为了应对突发情况而设立的，使用限制较多。

Sushi Samba是一家结合了日本和巴西风味的餐厅，提供独特的寿司和其他美食。这种文化融合的餐厅在美国和其他国家都颇受欢迎。

paragraphs.text: “He said, ‘Welcome to the dollhouse, baby.' I swear. How cool is that?”

这有多酷？这是一个口语化的表达，用于表示对某事的赞赏或惊讶。在这里，表达了说话者对‘dollhouse’的欢迎语的认可和兴奋。

paragraphs.text: She looked at me, mouth hung open, spoon suspended in midair.

勺子悬停在空中。“suspended”本义是悬挂或停留，这里形容勺子没有移动，暗示她在思考或惊讶的状态。
空中，半空中。这个词通常用来描述某物在地面以上的状态，给人一种悬浮的感觉。
看着我。这个短语在这里强调了两人之间的目光交流，可能暗示着情感或紧张的气氛。

paragraphs.text: “You have the coolest job I've ever heard of,” said Lily, who always talked about how she should've worked for a year before going back to school.

曾经听说过的。“ever”在这里强调时间的广泛性，表示在所有的时间里。这个短语通常用来引入某个令人惊讶或特别的事物。
本该工作。“should've”是“should have”的缩写，表示对过去的某种期望或建议。这里暗示Lily认为自己在回到学校之前应该先工作一段时间。

paragraphs.text: “Yeah, I'm sure you'd just love to work part-time to finance your obscenely expensive and utterly useless Ph.D. You would, wouldn't you? You're jealous that I get to bartend in an undergrad pub, get hit on by freshmen until four A.M. every night, and then head to class all day, aren't you? All of it knowing that if—and that's a big, fat if—you manage to finish at some point in the next seventeen years, you'll never get a job. Anywhere.” She plastered on a big, fake smile and took a swig of her Sapporo. Lily was studying for her Ph.D. in Russian Literature at Columbia and working odd jobs every free second she wasn't studying. Her grandmother barely had enough money to support herself, and Lily wouldn't qualify for grants until she'd finished her master's, so it was remarkable she'd even come out that night.

annotations.explanation: 资助，提供资金。这里指通过工作来支付学费和生活费用。
极其昂贵的。“obscene”通常指令人反感的，这里用来形容学费高得离谱。
完全无用的。“utterly”表示完全，强调其无用性。
博士学位，Doctor of Philosophy的缩写。通常是学术界的最高学位，要求进行深入研究。
在酒吧工作，调酒。“bartend”指在酒吧里调制和提供饮料的工作。

被搭讪。这里指她在酒吧工作时受到男性顾客的注意和追求。
凌晨四点。这里强调了她工作到很晚的生活方式。
去上课。“head to”是一个口语化的表达，意为前往某地。
一个很大的假设。“big, fat”是口语中用来强调某事的形容词，表示这个假设的可能性很小。
设法完成。这里指完成学业的艰难。
助学金，通常是政府或机构提供的资金支持，学生不需要偿还。
显著的，值得注意的。这里指她能够在经济压力下仍然出门的情况。
札幌啤酒，源自日本札幌市，是一种非常受欢迎的啤酒品牌。

paragraphs.text: I took the bait, as I always did when she bitched about her life. “So why do you do it, Lil?” I asked, even though I'd heard the answer a million times.

annotations.explanation: 上钩。这个短语源于钓鱼，指的是鱼被诱饵吸引而上钩。在这里比喻说话者被对方的抱怨所吸引，参与到对话中。
抱怨，发牢骚。‘bitch’本义是指母狗，但在口语中常用作动词，表示对某事不满并发出抱怨。这个表达通常带有负面情绪，暗示说话者对生活的不满。
尽管，虽然。这个短语用于引导让步状语从句，表示尽管前面的情况成立，后面的情况仍然成立。
一百万次。这个表达是夸张的说法，表示某事发生过很多次，强调说话者对这个答案的熟悉程度。
Lil是一个常见的昵称，通常是‘Lillian’或‘Lily’的缩写。在文学作品中，昵称常用来表现角色之间的亲密关系或特定的性格特征。

paragraphs.text: Lily snorted and rolled her eyes again. “Because I love it!” she sang sarcastically. And even though she'd never admit it because it was so much more fun to complain, she did love it. She'd developed a thing for Russian culture ever since her eighth-grade teacher told her that Lily looked how he had always pictured Lolita, with her round face and curly black hair. She went directly home and read Nabokov's masterpiece of lechery, never allowing the whole teacher-Lolita reference to bother her, and then read everything else Nabokov wrote. And Tolstoy. And Gogol. And Chekhov. By the time college rolled around, she was applying to Brown to work with a specific Russian lit professor who, upon interviewing seventeen-year-old Lily, had declared her one of the most well read and passionate students of Russian literature he'd ever met—undergrad, graduate, or otherwise. She still loved it, still studied Russian grammar and could read anything in its original, but she enjoyed whining about it more.

annotations.explanation: 发出哼声，通常表示不屑或轻蔑。这里表明Lily对某事的不满或讽刺。
讽刺地唱。‘sarcastically’指用讽刺的语气表达，通常是为了表达与字面意思相反的情感。
对……产生了兴趣或喜好。‘thing’在这里指一种强烈的兴趣或爱好。

想象洛丽塔。‘Lolita’是纳博科夫小说中的一个角色，代表一种复杂的情感和文化背景，通常与禁忌和欲望相关。
淫荡的杰作。‘lechery’指的是过度的性欲或放荡，通常带有贬义。这里指的是纳博科夫的《洛丽塔》。
老师与洛丽塔的关联。这里提到的‘reference’指的是老师提到Lily与洛丽塔的相似之处，这种比较可能让Lily感到不适。

paragraphs.text: “Well, anytime you feel like getting back in touch with reality, you know where to find me,” Lily said, taking her MetroCard out of her purse. “If you get a craving for a little ghetto, if you're just dying to keep it real in Harlem, well, my luxurious two-hundred-and-fifty-square-foot studio is all yours.”

paragraphs.text: “From the security camera,” she said when I stared at it. “They're everywhere around here, just so you know. paragraphs.text: “Well, between the cameras and the cards, they kind of know what everyone's doing,” she said as she dropped her Gucci logo tote on her desk. She began unbuttoning her very fitted leather blazer, a coat that looked supremely inadequate for the late-November weather. “I don't think they actually look at the cameras unless something's missing, but the cards tell everything. Like, every time you swipe it downstairs to get past the security counter or on the floor to get in the door, they know where you are. That's how they tell if people are at work, so if you have to be out—and you never will, but just in case something really awful happens—you'll just give me your card and I'll swipe it. That way you'll still get paid for all the days you miss, even if you go over. You'll do the same for me—everyone does it.”

极其不够。“supremely”表示极端、非常，通常用于强调某种状态或特质。“inadequate”指不足或不适合，结合在一起形容外套在寒冷天气中的无用。

paragraphs.text: Cut, place, fold, tape: Emily and I worked steadily through the morning, stopping only to call the downstairs messenger center each time we'd finished with twenty-five boxes. They'd hold them until we gave the green light for them to be fanned out all over Manhattan in mid-December. We'd already completed all of the out-of-town bottles during my first two days, and those were piled in the Closet waiting for DHL to pick them up. Considering each and every one was set to be sent first-day priority, arriving at their locations at the earliest possible time the very next morning, I wasn't sure what the rush was—considering it was only the end of November—but I'd already learned it was better not to ask questions. We would be FedExing about 150 bottles all over the world. The Priestly bottles would make it to Paris, Cannes, Bordeaux, Milan, Rome, Florence, Barcelona, Geneva, Brugges, Stockholm, Amsterdam, and London. Dozens to London! FedEx would jet them to Beijing and Hong Kong and Capetown and Tel Aviv and Dubai (Dubai!). They would be toasting Miranda Priestly in Los Angeles, Honolulu, New Orleans, Charleston, Houston, Bridgehampton, and Nantucket. And those all before any went out in New York—the city that contained all of Miranda's friends, doctors, maids, hair stylists, nannies, makeup artists, shrinks, yoga instructors, personal trainers, drivers, and personal shoppers. Of course, this was where most of the fashion-industry people were, too: the designers, models, actors, editors, advertisers, PR folks, and all-around style mavens would each receive a level-appropriate bottle lovingly delivered by an Elias-Clark messenger.

If you figure that all the domestic FedExes are somewhere in the twenty-dollar range, and all the international are about $60, then that equals $9,000 for FedEx. I think I heard somewhere that the messengers charge eleven bucks a package, so sending out 250 of those would be $2,750. And our time, well, if it takes us a full week to wrap everything, then added together, that's two full weeks of both our salaries, which is another four grand—”

paragraphs.text: At about one Emily announced she was hungry and was heading downstairs to get some lunch with a few of the girls in accessories. I assumed she meant she would pick up her lunch, since that's what we'd been doing all week, so I waited for ten minutes, fifteen minutes, twenty, but she never reappeared with her food. Neither of us had actually eaten in the dining room since I'd started in case Miranda called, but this was ridiculous. Two o'clock came and then two-thirty and then three, and all I could think about was how hungry I was. I tried calling Emily's cell phone, but it went directly to voice mail. Could she have died in the dining room? I wondered. Choked on some plain lettuce, or simply slumped over after downing a smoothie? I thought about asking someone to pick something up for me, but it seemed too prima donna–ish to ask a perfect stranger to fetch me lunch. After all, I was supposed to be the lunch-fetcher: Oh, yes, darling, I'm simply too important to abandon my post here wrapping presents, so I was wondering if you might pick me up a turkey and brie croissant? Lovely. I just couldn't do it. So when four o'clock rolled around and there was still no sign of Emily and no call from Miranda, I did the unthinkable: I left the office unattended.

annotations.explanation: 宣布，宣告。指公开地说出某事，通常带有重要性或正式性。
配饰，附属品。在时尚领域，指服装的附加物品，如首饰、手袋等。
再次出现。指某人或某物在消失后再次显现。
荒谬的，滑稽的。形容某事显得不合理或令人发笑。
语音邮件。指一种电话服务，允许来电者在无法接听时留下语音信息。
窒息，因吞咽不当而导致呼吸困难。这里暗示了对食物安全的担忧。
趴下，倒下。通常指因疲惫或不适而无力支撑身体。
喝下果昔。指快速喝下混合果汁饮料，通常是健康饮品。

午餐取餐者。这里是指负责为他人取餐的人，带有一种自嘲的意味。
放弃我的岗位。指在工作中离开自己的职责或位置，通常带有负面含义。
火鸡和布里奶酪可颂。是一种美味的三明治，结合了火鸡肉和法国布里奶酪，夹在可颂面包中。
不可思议的，难以想象的。形容某种行为极其不寻常或不被接受。

paragraphs.text: After peeking down the hall and confirming that Emily was nowhere in sight, I literally ran to the reception area and pushed the down button twenty times. Sophy, the gorgeous Asian receptionist, raised her eyebrows and looked away, and I wasn't sure if it was my impatience or her knowledge that Miranda's office was abandoned that made her look at me that way. No time to figure it out. The elevator finally arrived, and I was able to throw myself onboard even as a sneering, heroin-thin guy with spiky hair and lime green Pumas was pushing “Door Close.” No one moved aside to give me room even though there was plenty of space. And while this would've normally driven me crazy, all I could concentrate on was getting food and getting back, ASAP.

annotations.explanation: 向走廊里窥视。“peek”意为偷偷看，通常带有谨慎或好奇的意味。
字面上跑。“literally”表示确实如此，强调动作的真实和紧迫性。
接待区，通常是酒店或办公室的前台区域，负责接待来访者。
扬起眉毛，通常表示惊讶、怀疑或不屑的情绪。
不耐烦，指对等待或延迟的厌烦情绪。

annotations.phrase: knowledge that Miranda's office was abandoned
annotations.explanation: 关于米兰达的办公室被遗弃的知识。“abandoned”意为被遗弃的，通常指某物被抛弃或无人照管。
冲上电梯。“throw oneself”在这里形容一种急迫的动作，表示急切想要进入电梯。
冷笑，带有轻蔑或嘲讽的意味。
像海洛因一样瘦，形容人非常瘦弱，通常与吸毒有关。
青柠绿色的Puma运动鞋。“Pumas”是德国运动品牌Puma的鞋子，通常以其时尚和舒适著称。
按下“关门”按钮，表示想要尽快关闭电梯门。
让开，指让出空间或位置。
充足的空间，表示有足够的地方可以移动或站立。
让我发疯，形容某事让人极为烦恼或恼火。
专注于，指将注意力集中在某事上。
尽快，缩写自“As Soon As Possible”，常用于强调紧急性。

paragraphs.text: The entrance to the all-glass-and-granite dining room was blocked by a group of Clackers-in-training, all leaning in and whispering, examining each group of people who got off the elevator. Friends of Elias employees, I immediately recalled from Emily's description of such groups, obvious from their unmasked excitement to be standing at the center of it all. Lily had already begged me to take her to the dining room since it'd been written up in nearly every Manhattan newspaper and magazine for its incredible food quality and selection—not to mention its gaggle of gorgeous people—but I wasn't ready for that yet. Besides, due to the complex office-sitting schedule Emily and I negotiated each day so far, I'd yet to spend more time there than the two and a half minutes it took to choose and pay for my food, and I wasn't sure I ever would.

annotations.explanation: 全玻璃和花岗岩。形容这个餐厅的建筑材料，强调其现代和奢华的设计风格。
正在训练中的Clackers。这里的“Clackers”可能指的是一种特定的社交圈或职业群体，通常与时尚或社交活动相关。
倾身低语。形容这些人对周围环境的好奇和兴奋，似乎在讨论或观察他人。
仔细观察每一组人。这里的“examining”强调了他们的关注和好奇心，可能暗示着一种社交竞争。
毫不掩饰的兴奋。这里的“unmasked”表示没有隐藏或伪装，强调他们的真实情感。
一切的中心。形容这个餐厅是社交活动的热点，吸引了很多人的注意。

annotations.phrase: written up in nearly every Manhattan newspaper and magazine
annotations.explanation: 几乎在每一份曼哈顿的报纸和杂志上都有报道。强调这个餐厅的知名度和受欢迎程度。
令人难以置信的食物质量和选择。形容餐厅的食物非常出色，种类丰富。
一群迷人的人。“gaggle”通常指一群鹅，这里用作比喻，形容人群的喧闹和热闹。
复杂的办公室坐班安排。形容作者和Emily的工作安排很繁琐，可能需要协调多方。
每天进行协商。这里的“negotiated”表示双方就工作安排进行讨论和达成一致。
两分半钟。强调作者在餐厅的时间非常有限，暗示了对这个地方的陌生和不适应。

paragraphs.text: I pushed my way past the girls and felt them turn to see if I was anyone important. Negative. Weaving quickly, intently, I bypassed gorgeous racks of lamb and veal marsala in the entrees section and, with a push of willpower, cruised right past the sundried tomato and goat cheese pizza special (which resided on a small table banished to the sidelines that everyone referred to as “Carb Corner”). It wasn't as easy to navigate around the pièce de résistance of the room, the salad bar (also known just as “Greens,” as in “I'll meet you at Greens”), which was as long as an airport landing strip and accessible from four different directions, but the hordes let me pass when I loudly assured them that I wasn't going after the last of the tofu cubes. All the way in the back, directly behind the panini stand that actually resembled a makeup counter, was the single, lone soup station. Lone because the soup chef was the only one in the entire dining room who refused to make a single one of his offerings low fat, reduced fat, fat-free, low sodium, or low carb. He simply refused. As a result, his was the single table in the entire room without a line, and I sprinted directly toward him every day. Since it appeared that I was the only one in the entire company who actually bought soup—and I'd only been there a week—the higher-ups had slashed his menu to a solitary soup per day. I prayed for tomato cheddar. Instead, he ladled out a giant cup of New England clam chowder, proudly declaring it was made with heavy cream. Three people at Greens turned to stare. The only obstacle left was dodging the crowds around the chef's table, where a visiting chef in full whites was arranging large chunks of sashimi for what appeared to be adoring fans. I read the nametag on his starched white collar: Nobu Matsuhisa. I made a mental note to look him up when I got upstairs, since I seemed to be the only employee in the place who wasn't fawning all over him. Was it worse to have never heard of Mr. Matsuhisa or Miranda Priestly?

annotations.explanation: 绕过，避开。指的是故意不经过某个地方或物体，这里形容主角快速穿过食物区域。

每天只有一种汤。强调汤的选择非常有限，突显了主角的困境。

躲避人群。指在拥挤的地方小心翼翼地穿行，避免与人碰撞。
穿着全套厨师服的来访厨师。厨师服通常是白色的，象征着专业和卫生。
生鱼片。是一种日本料理，通常是新鲜生鱼切片，常与酱油和芥末一起食用。
对他过于溺爱或崇拜。形容人们对某人表现出极大的热情和关注，通常带有过度的意味。
米兰达·普里斯特利，小说《穿普拉达的女王》中的角色，象征着时尚界的权威和苛刻。
松久信幸，著名的日本厨师，以其高档的日本料理而闻名，尤其是寿司和生鱼片。

paragraphs.text: The petite cashier looked first at the soup and then at my hips when she rang me up. Or had she? I'd already grown accustomed to being looked up and down every time I went anywhere, and I could've sworn she was looking at me with the same expression I would've given a five-hundred-pound person with eight Big Macs arrayed in front of him: the eyes raised just enough as if to ask, “Do you really need that?” But I brushed my paranoia aside and reminded myself that the woman was simply a cashier in a cafeteria, not a Weight Watchers counselor. Or a fashion editor.

annotations.explanation: 娇小的，形容身材小巧的人。通常用于描述女性，强调她们的纤细和娇弱。

时尚编辑，负责时尚杂志内容的专业人士。这里暗示主角对外貌的担忧与时尚界的标准有关。

paragraphs.text: “So. Not many people buying the soup these days,” she said quietly, punching numbers on the register.

annotations.explanation: 购买汤。这里的“soup”可能是指某种特定的汤品，暗示着商店的生意不景气，也可能象征着生活中的某种需求或温暖。
这些天。指的是当前的时间段，通常用来强调与过去的对比，暗示某种变化或趋势。
她轻声说道。“quietly”指说话的声音小，可能暗示她的情绪低落或对当前情况的不满。
在收银机上输入数字。“punching numbers”指用手指按压按钮或键盘输入数据，通常用于描述收银员在处理交易时的动作。“register”是指收银机，商店中用于记录销售和处理付款的设备。

paragraphs.text: “Yeah, I guess not that many people like New England clam chowder,” I mumbled, swiping my card and willing her hands to move faster, faster.

annotations.explanation: 新英格兰蛤蜊浓汤。这是一种源自美国新英格兰地区的传统海鲜汤，主要成分包括蛤蜊、土豆、洋葱和奶油。它的浓郁口感和独特风味使其成为美国东北部的经典美食。

刷卡。指用信用卡或借记卡在支付终端上滑动以完成支付。这种方式在现代社会中非常普遍，方便快捷。

annotations.phrase: willing her hands to move faster

更快，更快。重复的用法强调了说话者的焦虑和急切心情，表现出一种迫切希望事情能迅速进行的情绪。

paragraphs.text: She stopped and turned her narrowed brown eyes directly toward mine. “No, I think it's because the soup chef insists on making these really fattening things—do you have any idea how many calories are in that? Do you have any idea how fattening that little cup of soup is? I'm just saying is, someone could put on ten pounds from just looking at it—” And you're not one who could afford to gain ten pounds, she implied.

annotations.explanation: 狭窄的棕色眼睛。这里的“narrowed”形容眼睛微微眯起，通常表示怀疑或不满的情绪。
汤厨师。指专门制作汤的厨师，通常在餐厅中负责汤品的调配和烹饪。
使人发胖的。通常指食物含有较高的卡路里或脂肪，容易导致体重增加。
卡路里。是衡量食物能量的单位，过多的卡路里摄入会导致体重增加。
增加十磅体重。“put on”在这里指增加体重，通常用于描述体重的变化。
负担得起增加十磅体重。这里的“afford”指的是在身体或健康上是否能够承受这样的变化，暗示说话者可能认为对方的体型不适合再增加体重。
暗示。指没有直接说出，而是通过言语或行为让人理解的意思。

paragraphs.text: Ouch. As if it hadn't been hard enough convincing myself that I was a normal weight for a normal height as all the tall, willowy Runway blondes had openly examined me, now the cashier was—for all intents and purposes—telling me I was fat? I snatched my takeout bag and pushed past the people, and walked into the bathroom that was conveniently located directly outside the dining room, where one could purge any earlier bingeing problems. And even though I knew that the mirror would reveal nothing more or less than it had that morning, I turned to face it head on. A twisted, angry face stared back at me.

annotations.explanation: 形容词，意为“苗条的，纤细的”。通常用来描述身材高挑、优雅的人，尤其是女性。
指的是模特行业中的金发女郎，尤其是在时装秀上走秀的模特。这个短语暗示了时尚界对身材和外貌的严格标准。
这个短语的意思是“在所有实际意义上”。它用来强调某事在实际操作中是如何被理解或看待的。
动词，意为“迅速抓取”。在这里，暗示了角色的焦虑和急迫感。
动词，意为“清除，排出”。在饮食或心理健康的语境中，通常指通过呕吐等方式清除体内食物，暗示了角色可能存在的饮食失调问题。
动词，意为“暴饮暴食”。通常指短时间内大量进食，常与饮食失调相关联。
动词，意为“揭示，显示”。在这里，指的是镜子反映出角色的外貌和内心感受。
形容词，意为“扭曲的，扭曲的”。在这里形容角色的面容，暗示了内心的痛苦和愤怒。

paragraphs.text: “What the hell are you doing here?” Emily all but shouted at my reflection. I whipped around in time to see her hanging her leather blazer through the handle of the Gucci logo tote, as she pushed her sunglasses on top of her head. It occurred to me that Emily had meant what she'd said three and a half hours before quite literally: she'd gone out for lunch. As in, outside. As in, left me all alone for three straight hours with no warning, practically tethered to a phone line with no hopes of food or bathroom breaks. As in, none of that mattered because I still knew I was wrong to leave and I was about to get screamed at for it by someone my own age. Blessedly, the door swung open and the editor in chief of Coquette strode in. She looked us both up and down as Emily grabbed my arm and steered me out of the bathroom and toward the elevator. We stood like that together, her clutching my arm and me feeling as though I'd just wet the bed. We were living one of those scenes where the kidnapper puts a gun to a woman's back in broad daylight and quietly threatens her as he leads her to his basement of torture.

annotations.explanation: 几乎大喊。‘all but’是一个习语，表示几乎、差不多，强调情感的强烈程度。
皮革西装外套。‘blazer’通常指一种休闲西装外套，搭配皮革材质显得更为时尚。
古驰标志的手提包。‘Gucci’是意大利著名奢侈品牌，‘tote’指一种大容量的手提包，通常用于购物或日常出行。
被束缚在电话线上。‘tethered’本义是用绳子或链子绑住，这里比喻被迫依赖电话，无法自由行动。

annotations.phrase: no hopes of food or bathroom breaks
annotations.explanation: 没有吃东西或上厕所的希望。‘bathroom breaks’是指短暂的上厕所时间，强调长时间无法休息的窘迫。
主编。‘editor in chief’是指负责整个出版物的最高编辑，通常负责内容的审核和决策。
大步走进来。‘strode’是‘stride’的过去式，表示以自信或急切的步伐走进，通常带有目的性。

annotations.phrase: looked us both up and down
annotations.explanation: 上下打量我们。这个短语表示仔细观察某人，通常带有评估或判断的意味。
紧握着我的手臂。‘clutch’表示用力抓住，通常表达出焦虑或紧张的情绪。
尿床。这个短语通常用来形容儿童在睡觉时失禁，这里用作比喻，表达主人公的尴尬和不安。
折磨的地下室。‘basement’是建筑物的底层，通常用来形容阴暗、压抑的地方，这里暗示了恐怖和绝望的情境。
大白天。这个短语通常用来形容在光天化日之下发生的事情，强调事件的公开性和不可思议性。

paragraphs.text: “How could you do this to me?” she hissed as she pushed me through Runway's reception-area doors and we hurtled together back to our desks. “As the senior assistant, I am responsible for what goes on in our office. I know you're new, but I've told you from the very first day: we do not leave Miranda unattended.”

annotations.explanation: 嘶嘶声，通常指用低声或生气的语气说话。这里形容她的声音带有愤怒和不满的情绪。

高级助理。‘senior’表示在职务或经验上较高，通常负责更多的责任和管理工作。
对发生的事情负责。‘responsible’表示有责任、义务，这里强调她对办公室事务的管理和监督。
无人看管的，未被照顾的。‘unattended’通常指没有人负责或照顾的状态，这里指的是不能让Miranda单独留在办公室。

让Miranda无人看管。这里的‘leave’指的是离开或放弃照顾，强调了对Miranda的重视和责任感。
Runway的接待区。‘Runway’可能是一个公司或品牌的名字，接待区通常是客户或访客进入办公室的第一印象之地。

paragraphs.text: “But Miranda's not here.” It came out as a squeak.

paragraphs.text: “But she could've called while you were gone and no one would've been here to answer the goddamn phone!” she screamed as she slammed the door to our suite. “Our first priority—our only priority—is Miranda Priestly. Period. And if you can't deal with that, just remember that there are millions of girls who would die for your job. Now check your voice mail. If she called, we're dead. You're dead.”

annotations.explanation: 该死的电话。‘goddamn’是一个强烈的咒骂词，用于表达愤怒或沮丧。在这里，强调了说话者对情况的不满。
猛地关上门。‘slam’指用力关闭，通常带有愤怒或不满的情绪。

paragraphs.text: “Sounds great. What was he?” Lily went out with different guys almost every night after getting off work, but had yet to complete her fraction. She had founded the Scale of Fractional Love one night after listening to a few of our guy friends rate the girls they were dating on their own invention, the Ten-Ten Scale. “She's a six, eight, B-plus,” Jake would declare of the advertising assistant he'd been set up with the night before. It was assumed everyone knew that it was a ten-point scale, with face always being the first numerical ranking, body the second, and personality coming in last with a slightly more generalized letter grade. Since there were clearly more factors at work in judging guys, Lily devised the Fractional Scale, which had a total of ten pieces that each earned a point. The Perfect Guy would obviously have all five of the primary pieces: intelligence, sense of humor, decent body, cute face, and any sort of job that fell under the generous umbrella of “normal.” Since it was next to impossible to find The Perfect Guy, someone could up their fraction by earning points on the secondary five, which included a definitive lack of psycho ex-girlfriends, psycho parents, or date-rapist roommates, and any sort of extracurricular interests or hobbies that weren't sports- or porn-related. So far, the highest anyone had received was a nine-tenths, but he had broken up with her.

与运动或色情相关的。这里的“porn”指色情内容，强调Lily对伴侣兴趣的选择标准。

paragraphs.text: Well, at first he was going strong at seven-tenths. He was a theater major at Yale and he's straight, and he could discuss Israeli politics so intelligently that he never once suggested that we ‘just nuke 'em,' so that was good.

红酒，一种由红葡萄酿造的酒，通常具有丰富的口感和深色的外观。红酒在许多文化中被视为社交和庆祝的饮品。
蜡质纸杯，指用蜡涂层的纸杯，通常用于盛装饮料，具有防水和保温的特性。这里形容杯子的质感和用途，适合用来喝酒。

paragraphs.text: “You're kidding,” I said softly, still not believing that he'd put all this together after I'd canceled our date.

annotations.explanation: 你在开玩笑。这是一种口语表达，通常用来表示对某事的惊讶或不相信。
轻声地，柔和地。这个词通常用来形容说话的音量或语气，表示不想引起他人注意或表达温柔的情感。
不相信。这个短语表示对某事的怀疑或不接受，暗示说话者对当前情况感到困惑或难以置信。
把这一切结合在一起。这个短语的本义是将不同的信息或元素整合成一个整体。在这里，它暗示对方能够理解并联系起之前的事件或信息。
在我取消约会之后。这个短语中的“canceled”表示取消，通常用于指代预定的活动或计划被叫停。这里暗示说话者对对方的反应感到意外，因为他们本来应该见面。

paragraphs.text: He handed me a cup of wine and tapped it with his. “No, I'm not. You think I was going to miss hearing about the first week of the rest of your life? To my best girl.”

annotations.explanation: 递给我。‘hand’是动词，表示用手给某人某物。
一杯酒。‘cup’指容器，这里特指盛酒的杯子。酒在许多文化中常常象征着庆祝或社交。
用他的杯子轻轻碰了碰。‘tap’是轻轻碰触的意思，通常用来表示祝酒或庆祝。
错过听到。‘miss’在这里表示希望能听到某事，‘hearing about’指听到某个话题或事件。

annotations.phrase: the first week of the rest of your life
annotations.explanation: 你余生的第一周。这是一个富有哲理的表达，暗示着生活的转折点或新开始。通常用来庆祝重要的生活变化，比如毕业、结婚等。
献给我最好的女孩。‘best girl’通常指最亲密的女性朋友或爱人，带有亲切和祝福的意味。

paragraphs.text: “Thank you.” I said, slowly taking a sip. “Thank you, thank you, thank you.”

annotations.explanation: 慢慢地小口喝。这句话中的“sip”指的是小口饮用，通常用来形容细致、享受的喝水方式。

annotations.phrase: Thank you, thank you, thank you
annotations.explanation: 谢谢你，谢谢你，谢谢你。重复表达感激之情，强调了说话者的感激程度，可能暗示着某种强烈的情感或对当前情境的重视。
